He then sprang forward from the right wing and was immedi- ⁶ ately followed by about 120 volunteers, picked soldiers of the first century 1. A roar of sound went up from all the military instruments‚ and with a loud shout the Caesarians charged.

In a pitched battle it was usual for both armies to meet at a run. But today Pompey on the advice, as was said, of Gaius Valerius Triarius, departed from this practice and ordered his men to await the enemy's onset‚ hoping that they would be exhausted before they closed2. When Caesar’s veterans ob- served that their enemy did not stir‚ they halted halfway of their own accord ; and there ensued the pause of which Lucan has made such dexterous use3. After a brief rest, they renewed the charge, hurled their pila and straightway drew their swords. The Pompeians stood their ground. Theirs was not indeed that fierce spirit of which the reluctant poet singS, that on the side of Caesar every blade was hot and deadly, that through arms, through bodies, struck the blows of his unconquerable soldiery4. But their resistance, if somewhat sluggish, was obstinate ; and their numbers told. Meanwhile, the bowmen, who had as yet no mark to aim at, adopting a device which has proved effective in more modern times, shot clouds of arrows into the air, which, as they fell, caused much annoyance to the Caesarian ranks⁵.
